articles.headline: Detroit Sets Its Future on a Foundation of Two-Tier Wages
articles.snippet: Once viewed as a desperate move, a two-tier wage system for longtime employees and new hires is being seen as important to Detroit’s future.
articles.abstract: Once viewed as a desperate move, a two-tier wage system for longtime employees and new hires is being seen as important to Detroit’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — They are a cornerstone of Chrysler’s unlikely comeback: 900 employees turning out a Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicle every 48 seconds of the working day at an assembly plant here.

articles.headline: Ban on E. Coli in Ground Beef Is to Extend to 6 More Strains
articles.snippet: The Department of Agriculture will include six additional strains of E. coli bacteria in new rules for banning ground beef sales.
articles.abstract: The Department of Agriculture will include six additional strains of E. coli bacteria in new rules for banning ground beef sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government will ban the sale of ground beef tainted with six toxic strains of E. coli bacteria that are increasingly showing up as the cause of severe illness from food. Officials have been under pressure from food safety advocates and some elected officials to do more to keep the potentially deadly bacteria out of meat, but the beef industry said the move was not needed and could force the price of ground beef to rise.

articles.headline: Fears Rattle Big Banks in France
articles.snippet: Concern about the banks’ ability to handle a Greek default caused shares to slide and raised the possibility that the government would need to intervene.
articles.abstract: Concern about the banks’ ability to handle a Greek default caused shares to slide and raised the possibility that the government would need to intervene.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — French banks moved toward the center of the European debt storm Monday as investor concern about their ability to handle a potential Greek default raised the possibility that France’s government might need to shore up the banks’ financial positions.

articles.headline: German Leader Faces Key Choices on Rescuing Euro
articles.snippet: Angela Merkel faces far-reaching decisions about how to deal definitively with the debt crisis in Europe and whether to allow Greece to default.
articles.abstract: Angela Merkel faces far-reaching decisions about how to deal definitively with the debt crisis in Europe and whether to allow Greece to default.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As Europe struggles to reverse a plunge in financial confidence, the world waits for Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, to make a fundamental choice. She, more than any other European politician, will have to either summon the leadership to rescue the euro or concede that the political will is not there.

articles.headline: Tech Blogger Parts With AOL
articles.snippet: AOL and Michael Arrington, the TechCrunch blogger, have parted over journalistic conflict of interest claims over CrunchFund, his venture capital company.
articles.abstract: AOL and Michael Arrington, the TechCrunch blogger, have parted over journalistic conflict of interest claims over CrunchFund, his venture capital company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — AOL last year paid $30 million to buy the TechCrunch blog, in large part for its outspoken, controversial and well-connected founder, Michael Arrington.

articles.headline: Wary Investors Start to Shun European Banks
articles.snippet: Money market funds have gradually grown wary of French banks, looking for safer places to park their cash.
articles.abstract: Money market funds have gradually grown wary of French banks, looking for safer places to park their cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a $225 million loan to BNP Paribas comes due Thursday at Legg Mason’s Western Asset management unit, managers at its money market funds will be exercising caution. Instead of renewing the loan as they would have as recently as two months ago, they are looking to park investors’ money elsewhere, avoiding BNP and other Continental banks in favor of institutions in Scandinavia, Canada and Britain.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Libya’s War-Tested Women Hope to Keep New Power
articles.snippet: The Libyan rebels’ unlikely victory over Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has propelled women in a traditional society into roles they never imagined.
articles.abstract: The Libyan rebels’ unlikely victory over Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has propelled women in a traditional society into roles they never imagined.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Aisha Gdour, a school psychologist, smuggled bullets in her brown leather handbag. Fatima Bredan, a hairdresser, tended wounded rebels. Hweida Shibadi, a family lawyer, helped NATO find airstrike targets. And Amal Bashir, an art teacher, used a secret code to collect orders for munitions: Small-caliber rounds were called “pins,” larger rounds were “nails.” A “bottle of milk” meant a Kalashnikov.

articles.headline: As Perry Rises, G.O.P. Elite Look Toward Romney
articles.snippet: The rising presidential candidacy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is stirring excitement for many Republican voters but is creating unease in some quarters of the party’s establishment.
articles.abstract: The rising presidential candidacy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is stirring excitement for many Republican voters but is creating unease in some quarters of the party’s establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The rising presidential candidacy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is stirring excitement for many Republican voters but is creating unease in some quarters of the party’s establishment, particularly over his views of Social Security, which are at the root of an intensifying competition with Mitt Romney.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: In Suburb, Battle Goes Public on Bullying of Gay Students
articles.snippet: A sprawling suburban school system north of Minneapolis is caught in the eye of one of the country’s hottest culture wars: how homosexuality should be discussed in the schools.
articles.abstract: A sprawling suburban school system north of Minneapolis is caught in the eye of one of the country’s hottest culture wars: how homosexuality should be discussed in the schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANOKA, Minn. — This sprawling suburban school system, much of it within Michele Bachmann’s Congressional district, is caught in the eye of one of the country’s hottest culture wars — how homosexuality should be discussed in the schools.

articles.headline: U.S. Embassy and NATO Headquarters Attacked in Kabul
articles.snippet: Insurgents launched a complex assault against the United States Embassy and a nearby NATO base, raising new questions about Kabul’s security.
articles.abstract: Insurgents launched a complex assault against the United States Embassy and a nearby NATO base, raising new questions about Kabul’s security.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Heavily armed insurgents wearing suicide vests struck Tuesday at two of the most prominent symbols of the American diplomatic and military presence in Kabul, the United States Embassy and the nearby NATO headquarters, demonstrating the Taliban’s ability to infiltrate even the most heavily fortified districts of the capital.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Ray Rivera and Jack Healy

articles.headline: From Europe, Mounting Pressure Over Greece’s Debt
articles.snippet: With diplomatic and market pressure rising, leaders of France, Germany and Greece are set to talk Wednesday.
articles.abstract: With diplomatic and market pressure rising, leaders of France, Germany and Greece are set to talk Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Facing market pressure to resolve the Greek debt crisis once and for all, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will hold a video conference call Wednesday evening with the embattled Greek prime minister, George Papandreou, French officials announced on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Soaring Poverty Casts Spotlight on ‘Lost Decade’
articles.snippet: Census numbers show new signs of distress among the middle class, as median incomes fell last year to levels last seen in 1997.
articles.abstract: Census numbers show new signs of distress among the middle class, as median incomes fell last year to levels last seen in 1997.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another 2.6 million people slipped into poverty in the United States last year, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday, and the number of Americans living below the official poverty line, 46.2 million people, was the highest number in the 52 years the bureau has been publishing figures on it.
